>So said Demyanovich, Craig - Apogent on 4/25/2003 --------------------
>I'=
ve never thought about testing equals() this way, simple idea though it
>is=
.  I test equals() according to its contract as specified in its
>documenta=
tion in Object.  Joshua Bloch also explains it well in his book,
>_Effectiv=
e Java_.  What I test for, then, are the following:  reflexivity,
>symmetry=
, transitivity, consistency and "non-nullity," to use Bloch's
>terms.
>I cr=
eate three identical instances of a class and use them in various
>asserts.=
  I could share if you like.  I'll have to think about what value
>your ide=
a might bring to my test.

This is what EqualsTester does. You provide thre=
e (or four) instances with the following properties:

a.equals(b) should be=
 true
a.equals(c) should be false
a.equals(d) should be false because d's t=
ype is a subclass of a's type

If a's type is "final", then d should be nul=
l and vice versa.

EqualsTester then runs through the full contract of Obje=
ct#equals().

Take care.
